Hi Anatoli,

Thank you very much for your suggestion. Actually, I need to c=
ompute equilibrium 
derivatives for the equilibrium compositions at each ti=
me step. I am trying to simulate the 
change in equilibrium compositon as a=
 function of time (or crank angle degree) in the 
combustion chamber of an =
internal combustion engine, similar to the computation that 
performs the b=
uilt-in Chemkin reactor for homogeneous combustion. Now I am looking at 
th=
e Cantera demo ignite.m that seems to perform this calculation for a variab=
le volume 
reactor. This might be other way to work it out, but I like your=
 idea of computing internal 
energy as a function of temperature and pressu=
re at each step and using matlab to 
compute the derivatives myself. Thanks=
 for your help.

Best Regards,
Peter

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "avmo=
khov" <avmokhov@...> wrote:
>
> Hello Peter,
> 
> It is not completely clea=
r for me what derivatives are you going to 
> calculate. If the mixture  co=
mposition does not change, every 
> thermodynamic function is a function of=
 two parameters. Thus you can 
> calculate partial derivative over one para=
meter when other parameter 
> is kept constant. For example, for the energy=
, partial derivative 
> over temperature at constant volume is Cv. AFAIK ca=
lculating partial 
> derivative of arbitrary thermodynamic parameter is not=
 (yet) 
> implemented in Cantera. As a very simple workaround I propose you=
 to 
> calculate in Cantera the energy as a function of temperature at fixe=
d 
> pressure and other way round with a reasonable step and then use a 
> =
spreadsheet or Matlab to calculate derivatives. Some fine point is 
> what =
type of derivatives do you want to calculate =96 frozen or 
> equlibrium? I=
f you want to calculate equilibrium derivatives, than 
> you need to calcul=
ate equilibrium composition on every step, while 
> when calculating "froze=
n" derivatives the composition should be kept 
> constant ("frozen).
> Hope=
 that this helps.
> Anatoli 
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Peter Pe=
rez" <plpd00@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> > 
> > I wonder if anyone has tried cal=
culating the derivatives of the 
> > thermodynamic properties from Cantera.=
 I need to compute 
> derivatives 
> > respect to T and P for the internal =
energy, i.e., du/dT and du/dp. 
> I 
> > would appreciate any advice in thi=
s direction. I am using the 
> Cantera 
> > toolbox in Matlab 7. Thank you =
very much for your attention.
> > 
> > Best Regards,
> > Peter
> >
>
